questions.text: An elderly patient on a vegetarian diet presenting with easy fatigability and pallor was investigated. Peripheral smear showed findings of macrocytic anemia. Investigations reveal elevated serum homocysteine levels and normal serum methylmalonic acid levels. What is the probable cause of anemia in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of megaloblastic anemia in a vegetarian with elevated homocysteine levels and normal serum methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels is due to folic acid deficiency.

Folic acid (Vitamin B9) is a water-soluble vitamin, and its active form is tetrahydrofolate (THFA). It acts as a carrier of one-carbon groups. THFA is involved in the formation of many coenzymes in metabolic systems, particularly for purine and pyrimidine synthesis, nucleoprotein synthesis, and maintenance in erythropoiesis.

Folate deficiency results in megaloblastic anemia, homocysteinemia, and neural tube defects (spina bifida, anencephaly) in the fetus.

Folic acid deficiency is associated with the following clinical and laboratory findings:

  • Raised MCV (normal range: 80–100 fL) - macrocytosis
  • Decrease in hemoglobin and hematocrit levels.
  • Normal MMA level
  • Elevated homocysteine levels.

where MCV is the mean corpuscular volume.

Patients with folate deficiency should be offered supplemental folic acid for the correction of the deficiency. Typically, oral folic acid (1 to 5 mg daily) suffices to treat folate deficiency 

Other options:

Option B: Vitamin B12 or cobalamin deficiency presents as anemia, fatigue, and pallor symptoms. Other presenting complaints may include peripheral neuropathy, glossitis, diarrhea, headaches, neuropsychiatric disturbances like dementia, and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord (SACD) leading to ataxia. A peripheral smear shows macrocytic anemia and hypersegmented neutrophils. Vitamin B12 deficiency is associated with raised serum methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels.

Option C: A patient with thiamine or vitamin B1 deficiency presents either dry Beriberi with predominantly neurological symptoms like neuropathy, muscle weakness, and wasting or wet Beriberi with predominant cardiac symptoms like cardiomegaly, tachycardia, high output congestive cardiac failure.

Option D: A patient with pyridoxine or vitamin B6 deficiency presents with symptoms of seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion, and normocytic anemia.

questions.text:
A patient presented with tendon xanthomas. His lipid profile showed serum cholesterol levels to be 283 mg/dL and serum LDL to be 202 mg/dL. He was started on lovastatin. What is the likely diagnosis?

LDL - Low density lipoprotein
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation with tendon xanthomas and elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia (FH).

Familial hypercholesterolemia  (type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia) is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors. This defect causes a decrease in the uptake of LDL and cholesterol. As a result, the blood levels of both LDL and cholesterol are elevated. Such patients are at increased risk to develop atherosclerosis and coronary artery disease.

Features of FH: 

  • Painful polyarthritis and tendinitis are common.
  • Physical findings seen are corneal arcus and tendon xanthomas over Achilles tendon and the dorsum of hands. Xanthomas are tumorous masses produced by foamy cell clusters (lipid-laden macrophages) found in the connective tissue of the skin and in tendons.

Diagnosis is done clinically based on hypercholesterolemia with 

  • LDL > 190 mg/dl, 
  • Family history of hypercholesterolemia and/or
  • Premature coronary artery disease.

Treatment includes lifestyle changes, restriction of a fatty diet, and pharmacotherapy with statins in heterozygous FH patients.

Recent drugs for specific treatment of homozygous FH are:

  • Lomitapide, a microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) inhibitor, and
  • Mipomersen, an antisense oligonucleotide against apoB.

The image below shows Achilles tendon xanthoma and a plain lateral radiograph of both ankles showing bilateral symmetrical swellings (arrows) superior to the calcaneum respectively.

 

 

Other options

Option B: Tangier’s disease is a hypolipoproteinemia caused by a mutation of the ABCA1 gene. Enlarged orange tonsils are pathognomonic. Low HDL levels are seen. There is an increased risk for atherosclerosis.

The image below shows enlarged yellow-orange colored tonsils in Tangier's disease.

 

Option C: Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency causes type I hyperlipoproteinemia due to defects in LPL or apo C-II. Eruptive xanthomas are seen. Chylomicrons and VLDL are elevated. LDL and HDL are low. There is no risk for coronary disease.

Option D: Familial hyperchylomicronemia syndrome is caused due to either LPL deficiency, ApoC-II deficiency, ApoA-V deficiency, or GPIHBP1 mutation. Clinically, patients present with recurrent episodes of severe abdominal pain due to acute pancreatitis. The retinal blood vessels may be opalescent and are called lipemia retinalis. Increased levels of triglycerides (mostly >1000 mg/dL) is seen. The risk of premature coronary heart disease is low.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child was brought to the outpatient clinic with features of hypotonia, irritability, and exaggerated startle response. Development milestones were delayed. Fundoscopic examination revealed the finding as shown in the image below. Which of the following enzymes is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of an infant presenting with hypotonia, irritability, exaggerated startle response, delayed milestones, and the image showing the cherry-red spot point to the diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease. The enzyme deficient in this condition is β-hexosaminidase A.

Tay-Sachs disease is a lipid storage disorder due to the deficiency of hexosaminidase A leading to the accumulation of GM2 gangliosides. It is classified into infantile, juvenile, and adult-onset forms based on the age at onset and clinical features.

Affected infants usually develop normally until 4-5 months of age. Clinical features of Tay-Sachs disease include:

  • Muscle weakness (hypotonia)
  • Seizures
  • Exaggerated startle response
  • Macrocephaly
  • Mental retardation
  • Macular cherry-red spots
  • Blindness
  • Developmental delay

The deficiency of β-hexosaminidase A and B causes Sandhoff's disease. The clinical manifestations of Sandhoff disease are similar to those of Tay-Sachs disease. Infants with Sandhoff disease have hepatosplenomegaly, cardiac involvement, and mild bony abnormalities.

Other options:

Option A: Fabry disease is an X-linked lysosomal storage disorder caused due to deficiency of α-Galactosidase. This leads to the accumulation of globotriaosylceramide. Clinical features include angiokeratomas, hypohidrosis, corneal and lenticular opacities, and painful acroparesthesias. Angiokeratomas are dark red to blue-black, flat or slightly raised, punctate lesions, usually seen between the umbilicus and the knees (called the bathing suit area) and the trunk.

Option B: Metachromatic leukodystrophy is a lysosomal storage disease caused due to deficiency of the enzyme arylsulfatase A. It leads to demyelination and the patient has a neurodegenerative course.

Option D: Gaucher disease is an autosomal recessive lysosomal storage disorder with a deficiency of acid-β-glucosidase. It leads to the accumulation of glucosylceramide. The features of this disease include growth retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, anemia, and Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the distal femur. Histology shows the presence of Gaucher cells with a characteristic wrinkled-paper appearance. Mental retardation is seen in infants.

questions.text: The echocardiography report of a 35-year-old woman hailing from China indicates dilated cardiomyopathy. Which of the following conditions can explain her diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient is probably suffering from Keshan's disease, which is due to selenium deficiency.

Keshan disease is endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women residing in regions of China where dietary intake of selenium is low. Mainly dilated cardiomyopathy is characteristic, and may also result in cardiomegaly, congestive cardiac failure and fulminant cardiogenic shock.

Selenium is an important trace element that is a part of the 21st amino acid selenocysteine. There are many selenium-containing enzymes such as:

  • Glutathione peroxidase
  • De-iodinase
  • Thioredoxin reductase

Selenium is also an intracellular antioxidant that complements the role of vitamin E. Dietary sources of selenium include seafood, muscle meat, and some cereals.

questions.text: Which Vitamin forms a part of Coenzyme A and acyl carrier protein (ACP)?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic Acid (Vitamin B5) acts as the pantetheine functional moiety in Coenzyme A and acyl carrier protein (ACP)

Vitamin B5 plays a central role in acyl group metabolism.

Functions of CoA (Coenzyme A) :

Takes part in the reactions of 

  • Citric acid cycle
  • Fatty acid oxidation
  • Acetylations
  • Cholesterol synthesis

ACP plays a major role in Fatty Acid synthesis

Other options :

Option A: Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) is responsible for the coenzymes flavin mononucleotide (FMN) and Flavin-adenine-dinucelotide (FAD)

Option B: Niacin (Vitamin B3) helps in the formation of coenzymes Nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD) and NADP

Option D: Pyridoxine (Vitamin B6) forms Pyridoxal Phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme.

Related Pearl: Active Forms and Functions of Water-Soluble Vitamins

Coenzyme

Name

Function

Thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP)

Decarboxylation

Transketolase reaction

Donor of methyl/formyl group

Methylcobalamin and Adenosylcobalamin

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false regarding epigenetic modification:

choices.text: It causes the alteration of gene expression without mutation
The acetylation of histone favors active transcription
Genomic imprinting is a phenomenon involved in epigenetic gene inactivation
DNA methylation is restricted between cytosine and guanine residues connected by hydrogen bonds

questions.solution:
DNA methylation usually occurs between cytosine and guanine residues connected by phosphodiester bond(CpG) island on the same strand.

Epigenetics is defined as heritable chemical changes in gene expression that are not caused by the alteration in the gene sequence. It alters gene expression without the mutation. Epigenetic modification can cause both gene activation and inactivation. If it causes gene inactivation, it is known as Genomic imprinting.  

The epigenetic modification includes:

  • DNA methylation is usually restricted to cytosines of CpG dinucleotides, which are abundant throughout the genome. CpG islands in promoter regions are typically unmethylated, and the lack of methylation facilitates transcription.
  • Acetylation and deacetylation of lysine residues in core histones which activates and deactivates gene expression respectively. Acetylation of histone favors active transcription.
  • Methylation of histones: Histone Methylation Mostly Makes DNA Mute.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl is brought with a history of impaired vision. On examination, she has light hair, light skin color, and pale blue iris. The child has a normal IQ. Which of the following are not derived from the precursor amino acid, whose metabolism is impaired in this child?

DOPA- dihydroxyphenylalanine, GABA- Gamma-aminobutyric acid
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a child with impaired vision, light hair, light skin color, and pale blue iris with a normal IQ is suggestive of albinism, which is a disorder of tyrosine metabolism where there is a defect in melanin synthesis. Tyrosine is not the precursor amino acid of GABA (γ-aminobutyric acid); it is glutamate.

Tyrosine is a precursor of melanin, thyroxin, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).

  • Formation of DOPA: Tyrosine is hydroxylated by tyrosinase to form dihydroxy phenylalanine or DOPA. Tyrosinase is a monooxygenase that contains copper.
  • Formation of melanin: Tyrosinase acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which is then converted to indolequinone. The indolequinone is polymerized to form melanin.
  • Formation of catecholamines: Epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine. They are produced by the adrenal medulla and sympathetic ganglia.
  • Formation of thyroid hormones: Tyrosine residues are iodinated to form 3-mono-iodo-tyrosine (MIT) and 3,5-di-iodo-tyrosine (DIT). These are coupled to give rise to triiodothyronine (T3) and tetraiodothyronine (thyroxine or T4).

The series of reactions involving the production of catecholamines is shown in the image below.

Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes leading to hypopigmentation. It is either due to defective melanosomes or defective protein involved in the formation and transfer of melanin.
 
There are 7 types of nonsyndromic albinism (OCA1 to OCA7). OCA type 1 is characterized by reduced or absent tyrosinase activity. Clinical features include white hair, white skin, and iris appearing blue-grey in oblique light. Ocular manifestations include photophobia, nystagmus, and decreased visual acuity. The IQ of the child will be normal.

questions.text: Which of the following steps in the metabolism of Vitamin D requires sunlight?
questions.solution:
In the metabolism of vitamin D, the conversion of 7-dehydrocholesterol to cholecalciferol requires sunlight.

Vitamin D metabolism occurs in 3 steps:

Step 1- Skin: 7-dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in cholesterol synthesis that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a nonenzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yielding cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream. Note that 7-Dehydrocholesterol and cholecalciferol already contain one hydroxy group.

Step 2- Liver:  Cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to 25-hydroxycholecalciferol. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D–binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.

Step 3- Kidney: 25-hydroxycholecalciferol is converted to 1,25 dihydroxycholecalciferol, the biologically active form by the enzyme 1α-hydroxylase.

questions.text:
Which of the following is not associated with G6PD deficiency?

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD)

choices.text: Equal incidence in males and females
Predisposes the patient to oxidative stress

questions.solution:
G6PD Deficiency does not have an equal incidence in males and females. It is an X-linked recessive (XLR) disorder, hence males are more affected than females.

Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency causes congenital hemolytic anemia due to enzyme deficiency. G6PD is required to generate NADPH while oxidizing glucose-6-phosphate in the hexose monophosphate pathway (HMP). G6PD deficiency leads to reduced NADPH levels (option B) which then reduces the level of reduced glutathione. Reduced glutathione is required to protect the cells against oxidative stress to RBCs and hemolysis. 

Clinically, most patients are asymptomatic. When exposed to triggers like fava beans, infections, drugs such as primaquine, chloroquine, sulfonamides/sulfones, dapsone, and nitrofurantoin patient develops:

  • Episodic hemolysis, both intravascular and extravascular
  • Hemolytic anaemia
  • Hemoglobinemia
  • Hemoglobinuria

Increased oxidative damage to RBCs leads to the formation of denatured precipitates known as Heinz bodies. These bodies can damage the RBC membrane leading to intravascular hemolysis. Additionally, when such RBCs pass through the splenic cords, macrophages pluck out these precipitates, giving them the characteristic appearance of bite cells. 

The images below show the presence of Heinz bodies and bite cells.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is found to have right-sided colon cancer. His father had similar colon cancer and died at the age of 40. His paternal aunt suffers from endometrial cancer and his paternal uncle also suffers from urothelial cancer. There is no history of familial adenomatous polyposis. Abnormality in which of the following DNA repair mechanisms is responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Lynch syndrome or hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC) and mismatch repair is the defective DNA repair mechanism here. 

HNPCC is an autosomal dominant genetic condition that is associated with a high risk of colon cancer as well as other cancers including endometrial cancer (second most common), cancers of the stomach, ovary, ureters, etc. It is the most common cause of the syndromic form of colon cancer. Colon cancers are seen at younger ages and usually on the right side.

DNA mismatch repair proteins function as spell checkers during DNA replication by correcting the incorrect pairing. In HNPCC, the proofreading function of the mismatch repair systems (majorly MLH1 and MSH2) is lost leading to the accumulation of errors throughout the genome. The genomes of these patients show microsatellite instability, which is characterized by changes in the length of short repeats.

Other options:

Option A: Defects in the nucleotide excision repair pathway are seen in patients with xeroderma pigmentosum.

Option B: Defects in non-homologous end-joining are seen in patients with subacute combined immunodeficiency syndrome (SCID).

Option C: Defects in DNA base excision repair are seen in patients with MUTYH-associated polyposis (MAP) syndromes.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about lipogenesis stimulated by Insulin?

choices.text: Decreases the transport of  glucose into the cells

questions.solution:
Insulin decreases intracellular cAMP level to stimulate lipogenesis.

Insulin stimulates lipogenesis by

  • Increasing acetyl-CoA carboxylase.
  • Increases the transport of glucose into the cell.
  • Activates pyruvate dehydrogenase in the adipose tissue (fatty acid synthesis and glycerol-3-phosphate for triacylglycerol synthesis via esterification of the newly formed fatty acids)
  • Decreasing the level of intracellular cAMP (this inhibits lipolysis in adipose tissue, reducing the concentration of plasma-free fatty acids and, therefore, long-chain acyl-CoA, which are inhibitors of lipogenesis)

questions.text: Which of the following is not a substrate for glucose formation?
questions.solution:
Acetyl coenzyme A (CoA) is not a substrate for glucose formation.

Acetyl CoA and compounds that give rise to acetyl CoA alone like acetoacetate, lysine, and leucine cannot give rise to a net synthesis of glucose. This is because of the irreversible nature of the pyruvate dehydrogenase complex, which converts pyruvate to acetyl CoA. These compounds give rise to ketone bodies instead.

The synthesis of glucose in the body, in the absence of dietary carbohydrates, occurs in two ways:

  • From liver glycogen, by a process known as glycogenolysis in the absence of dietary carbohydrates, for up to 24 hours.
  • De novo, from non-carbohydrate sources, by a process known as gluconeogenesis, when glycogen stores have depleted. This occurs primarily in the liver and to a lesser extent in the kidneys.

In gluconeogenesis, the substrates can be:

  • Oxaloacetate (from its conjugate acid, oxaloacetic acid) is a direct precursor of phosphoenolpyruvate
  • Pyruvate is an α-keto acid that can be converted to glucose.
  • Alanine is a glucogenic amino acid that is transaminated to form pyruvate by the enzyme alanine amino-transferase in the liver.
  • Lactate obtained from anaerobic glycolysis is released from skeletal muscles and RBCs into the blood. This is taken up by the liver in the Cori cycle to be oxidised to pyruvate, to eventually synthesize glucose 
  • Glycerol from adipose tissue is converted to dihydroxyacetone phosphate in the liver, which itself is an intermediate of glycolysis and gluconeogenesis.

The steps and enzymes involved in gluconeogenesis are shown in blue in the flowchart below.

questions.text: A baby was brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and hair loss. On examination, the following findings are noted. Identify the mineral deficiency leading to this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica seen with zinc deficiency.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremor, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, etc.

Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and periorificial(perianal, perigenital, perioral) regions are commonly seen as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

Other options-

Option A- Niacin deficiency leads to Pellagra which is characterized by diarrhea, dermatitis, and dementia. Dermatitis is seen in sun-exposed areas and presents as hyperpigmentation around the neck known as Casal's necklace. An image of Casal's necklace is shown below.

Option C- Riboflavin deficiency manifests as glossitis, cheilitis, magenta-colored tongue, angular stomatitis, and circumcorneal vascularization as shown below.

Option D- Copper deficiency can present as anemia, cardiovascular defects including aneurysms, hypopigmentation, and neurological symptoms such as ataxia.

questions.text: A non-essential amino acid is involved in the first step of heme synthesis. Which of the following is not a derivative of this amino acid?
questions.solution:
The non-essential amino acid involved in the first step of heme synthesis is glycine. Among the given options Melanin is a derivative of tyrosine and not glycine. 

Glycine is the simplest amino acid. It is non-essential and is glucogenic. It is involved in Heme biosynthesis, which is initiated by the condensation of succinyl-CoA and glycine in the presence of pyridoxal phosphate and δ-aminolevulinate synthase (ALA synthase) to produce δ-aminolevulinate. The Other products obtained from glycine are:

  • Creatine (from glycine, arginine, and methionine)
  • Serine (by reversal of serine hydroxymethyl transferase reaction)
  • Collagen (every third residue is glycine)
  • Glutathione (from glutamic acid, cysteine, and glycine)
  • C4, C5, and N7 of the purine ring structure

Tyrosine is a precursor of melanin, thyroxine, epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA).

  • Formation of DOPA: Tyrosine is hydroxylated by tyrosinase to form dihydroxy phenylalanine or DOPA. Tyrosinase is a copper-containing monooxygenase enzyme.
  • Formation of melanin: Tyrosinase acts on DOPA to form dopaquinone, which is then converted to indolequinone. The indolequinone is polymerized to form melanin.

questions.text: A patient on anti-tubercular treatment presents with a tingling sensation and paresthesia in the lower limbs. Her peripheral blood smear examination shows microcytic anemia. Which of the following enzyme assay is used to diagnose the deficient vitamin in this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical features of tingling sensation, paresthesias , and microcytic anemia in a patient on anti-tubercular treatment are suggestive of the adverse effect of isoniazid. The vitamin deficient in this patient is pyridoxine/vitamin B6. Therefore, the RBC transaminase enzyme assay is used to diagnose vitamin B6 deficiency. 

Isoniazid is the first-line antitubercular drug that inhibits the production of mycolic acid. It is a bactericidal drug against tubercle bacilli.

Peripheral neuritis occurs due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Patients present with clinical features of pyridoxine/vitamin B6 deficiency, which include paresthesias, numbness, and tingling sensation. other features include seborrhea, glossitis, convulsions, neuropathy, depression, confusion, and microcytic anemia.

The most widely used method to know the vitamin B6 nutritional status is by measuring the RBC transaminase activity.

Therefore, pyridoxine 10 mg/day (vitamin B6) is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamine)

Serum methyl malonate level

Related Pearl: Vitamin Deficiency States (Water-soluble Vitamins)

questions.text: Which of the following blot transfer techniques is used to detect specific sequences of DNA?
questions.solution:
Southern blot transfer technique can be used to detect specific sequences of DNA. It involves the following steps.

  • DNA from a cell line or tissue is digested into fragments by restriction enzymes
  • The fragments are embedded in agarose or polyacrylamide gel and subjected to electrophoresis. This separates the fragments based on their charge and size
  • The electrophoresed fragments are then denatured with a mild alkali and transferred to nitrocellulose or nylon paper
  • A labelled DNA probe is added, which hybridizes with complementary strands of DNA
  • The hybridisation is visualised by X-raying the film or using an image screen

Other options:

  • Western blot is used to detect and quantify specific protein molecules
  • Northern blot is used to detect and quantify specific RNA molecules
  • South-western blot or overlay blot is used to examine protein-protein or protein-nucleic acid interactions

questions.text: Which anticoagulant present in the light blue vacutainer is used for plasma glucose estimation?
questions.solution:
Light blue vacutainers contain the anticoagulant sodium citrate.

Vacutainer Additive Uses
Light grey Sodium fluoride and potassium oxalate Blood glucose estimation
Light green Lithium Heparin Plasma testing
Light blue Sodium citrate Coagulation tests (APTT and
prothrombin time)

Citrated plasma generated from whole blood is commonly utilized in laboratory testing for hemostasis. The recommended procedure involves the collection of specimens in tubes that are filled with a solution containing 3.2% sodium citrate (109 mM). The appropriate ratio for this collection is 9 parts blood to 1 part anticoagulant. The primary objective of citrate is to effectively eliminate calcium ions, which play a crucial role in the process of blood coagulation.

The following image shows color coding of vacutainers with the anticoagulant used and their practical uses:

Though the grey tube is typically considered the most specific one for use in sample collection for glucose estimation, it is not necessarily the only one suitable. The citrate tube can also be used for sample collection for glucose estimation and considering the color of the top is mentioned as sky blue, the best answer here is sodium citrate.

questions.text: Where does the Krebs–Henseleit cycle cycle take place?
questions.solution:
Ornithine cycle/Krebs–Henseleit cycle/Urea cycle occurs in both the cytoplasm and mitochondria.

The reactions that take place both in the cytoplasm and mitochondria are:

  • H: Heme synthesis
  • U: Urea cycle
  • G: Gluconeogenesis
  • Pathway: Pyrimidine synthesis

Urea cycle disorders are all characterized by hyperammonemia, encephalopathy, and respiratory alkalosis. This is due to an accumulation of the precursors of urea, namely ammonia and glutamine.

The enzymes involved in the urea cycle with their related disorders are given below:

  • Carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase (CPS) 1 deficiency (hyperammonemia type 1) - rare and characterized by severe hyperammonemia.
  • Ornithine transporter deficiency (HHH syndrome) - is characterized by hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria.
  • Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency (hyperammonemia type 2) - is inherited as an X-linked trait. Characterized by hyperammonemia and elevated glutamine levels in blood and CSF.
  • Argininosuccinate synthetase deficiency - is characterized by increased citrulline, citrullinuria, and hyperammonemia.
  • Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency- leads to argininosuccinic acidemia and metabolic acidosis. Hyperammonemia is less severe, and argininosuccinate is found in urine and CSF.
  • Arginase deficiency- mild variety. Characterized by hyperargininemia and argininuria.

Clinical features of urea cycle disorders are common to all and include vomiting, avoidance of high-protein foods, intermittent ataxia, irritability, lethargy, and severe mental retardation. 

Long terms treatment consists of a protein-restricted diet.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

Related Pearl: Sites of various pathways in cell

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is likely to be most abundant in collagen?
questions.solution:
The most abundant amino acid in collagen is glycine.

Collagen is the most abundant protein in the animal world. It consists of three alpha chains held together by hydrogen bonds forming a triple helical structure.

A striking characteristic of collagen is the occurrence of glycine residues at every third position, (Gly-X-Y) repeats.

Proline and hydroxyproline confer rigidity on the collagen molecule. Hydroxyproline and hydroxylysine are formed by the post-translational hydroxylation of proline and lysine residues. This hydroxylation is catalyzed by the enzyme prolyl and lysyl hydroxylase, and cofactors are ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and α-ketoglutarate.

Intracellular steps in the synthesis of collagen:

  • Signal peptide cleavage
  • Hydroxylation of prolyl residues and some lysyl residues, glycosylation of some hydroxylysyl residues
  • Intrachain and interchain S–S bonds formation in extension peptides
  • Triple helix formation

Extracellular steps in the synthesis of collagen:

  • Amino- and carboxyl-terminal propeptides cleavage
  • Collagen fibers assembly in quarter-staggered alignment
  • Oxidative deamination of h -amino groups of lysyl and hydroxylysyl residues to aldehydes
  • Intra- and interchain cross-links formation via Schiff bases and aldol condensation products

Related Pearl: Synthesis of collagen and its disorders

1. Collagen backbone Preprocollagen - Glycin-proline-lysine
2. Hydroxylation

Of proline and lysine in the presence of Vit C.

Deficiency of Vit C causes Scurvy.
3. Glycosylation Formation of procollagen and resulting triple helix
4. Cleavage of terminals of procollagen Resulting in the formation of tropocollagen
5. Cross-linking by lysyl oxidase (copper-containing enzyme)

Formation of mature collagen.

Defect causes Menkes disease and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome)

questions.text: If the percentage of thymine residues in DNA is 28%. What is the percentage of cytosine?
questions.solution:
The percentage of cytosine in the DNA is 22%.

As per the Chargaff's rule, in the DNA molecules, the concentration of deoxyadenosine (A) equals that of thymidine (T), and the concentration of deoxyguanosine (G) equals that of deoxycytidine (C). Therefore, A=T and G=C.

In the question, the concentration of thymine is given as 28%, therefore the concentration of adenine is also 28%, both of which add up to 56%. The remaining 44% (100-56) of the DNA consists of G-C base pairs. Of which the guanine constitutes 22% and the cytosine constitutes another 22%.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest feature in vitamin A deficiency?

choices.text: Loss of sensitivity to green light

questions.solution:
Loss of sensitivity to green light is the earliest feature of vitamin A deficiency.

Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin that can occur as carotenoids (most common - beta carotene from plant sources) or retinoids (from animal sources). Dietary sources of vitamin A are liver, fish, eggs, dark green, and deeply coloured fruits and vegetables.

3 forms of retinoids are:

  • Retinal is required mainly for normal vision (present in the visual pigment rhodopsin).
  • Retinol is important for the normal functioning of the reproductive system.
  • Retinoic acid has a role in the regulation of gene expression and tissue differentiation.

The sequence of visual defects in vitamin A deficiency:

  1. Impairment of the eye to adapt to dim light
  2. Night blindness
  3. Bitot spots on the conjunctiva - white patches of keratinized epithelium on the sclera
  4. Prolonged deficiency of vitamin A → xerophthalmia (dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea)
  5. If xerophthalmia is not treated, it results in keratomalacia (softening of the cornea), corneal ulceration, corneal scarring and ultimately complete blindness.

The image below shows a Bitot's spot which is pathognomic of vitamin A deficiency.

Other manifestations of vitamin A deficiency:

  • General impairment of immunity
  • Keratinization of skin (phrynoderma/toad skin)

questions.text: Which of the following lipid metabolic pathways is correctly matched with their rate-limiting enzyme?

choices.text: Ketone body synthesis - cytosolic HMG CoA synthase
Fatty acid β oxidation - Acetyl CoA carboxylase

questions.solution:
The correctly matched lipid metabolic pathway with its rate-limiting enzyme is bile-acid synthesis - 7α hydroxylase. It converts cholesterol into 7α hydroxycholesterol.

The activity of the enzyme is regulated by negative feedback mainly via the nuclear bile acid–binding receptor, farnesoid X receptor (FXR). When the size of the bile acid pool(mainly chenodeoxycholic acid) in the enterohepatic circulation increases, FXR is activated and transcription of 7α hydroxylase is suppressed. Whereas, 7α hydroxylase activity is enhanced by endogenous and dietary cholesterol. 

The rate-limiting enzyme in cholesterol synthesis is HMG CoA reductase. Cytosolic HMG CoA synthase is involved in cholesterol synthesis whereas mitochondrial HMG CoA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme of ketone body synthesis. (Options A and B)

The fatty acid oxidation in our body predominantly occurs by β oxidation and the rate-limiting step is carnitine palmitoyl-transferase-I (CPT-I) present in the outer mitochondrial membrane. It helps transport an activated fatty acid (Acyl CoA) inside the mitochondria from the cytosol by binding to carnitine. (Option D)       

Acetyl CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting step of fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: A young chemist notices a reaction system in which the rate of conversion of substrates to product is equal to the rate at which products are converted back to substrates. Which of the following properties regarding this reaction system is true?

choices.text: The equilibrium constant is a ratio of the reaction rates
The rate constants  of the forward and backward reactions are equal
The value of equilibrium constant increases with increase in catalyst or enzyme concentration

questions.solution:
Among the given options, Equilibrium is a dynamic state is the correct option.

In an equilibrium state, Although there is no net change in the concentration of substrates or products, individual substrate, and product molecules are continually being interconverted and hence it is said to be dynamic.

Some important properties of a system at equilibrium are:

  • The equilibrium constant (Keq) is a ratio of the reaction rate constants (not the reaction rates). 
  • At equilibrium, the reaction rates (not the rate constants) of the forward and back reactions are equal. 
  • The numerical value of the constant can be calculated by finding the concentrations of substrates and products.
  • If Keq is more than 1, the forward reaction is favoured. In such instances, the reaction is spontaneous and exothermic.
  • The concentration of the enzyme does not affect the Keq. The concentration of enzyme certainly increases the rate of reaction; but not the Keq or the ultimate state. Catalysts increase the rate of reaction but do not alter the equilibrium.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought with hypotonia and loss of motor milestones. On examination, hepatosplenomegaly and macular cherry-red spot are noted. Foam cells are seen on bone marrow biopsy. Which is the most likely deficient enzyme in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of progressive neurodegeneration (loss of motor milestones, hypotonia) along with hepatosplenomegaly, macular cherry-red spot, and foam cells on bone marrow biopsy point to a diagnosis of Niemann-Pick disease. The enzyme deficient in this disease is sphingomyelinase.

Niemann-Pick disease is disorder of infancy which is almost always fatal by 2-3 years of age. Although the affected infants are normal at birth, they soon present with failure to thrive, hepatosplenomegaly, and rapid psychomotor retardation. Over time, there is severe loss of motor function and deterioration of intellect and death occurs by 3 years of age.

Niemann-Pick disease occurs due to the deficient activity of acid sphingomyelinase enzyme. There is extensive accumulation of sphingomyelin in the monocyte-macrophage system. Lipid laden foam cells are observed in bone marrow and lymph nodes. The diagnosis is confirmed by measuring the sphingomyelinase levels in the peripheral leucocytes. 

The management of Niemann-Pick disease is mostly supportive, such as physical therapy and a feeding tube for nutrition. Olipudase alfa has been recently approved for non-CNS manifestations of Niemann-Pick disease. 

Other options:

Option B: Hexoseaminidase A deficiency is seen in Tay-Sachs disease. While it also presents with progressive neurodegeneration and macular cherry-red spot, there is no organomegaly and lysosomes with onion skin are seen. 

Option C: Glucocerebrosidase deficiency is seen in Gaucher disease. The patients present with hematological abnormalities, organomegaly, and skeletal manifestations in the form of bone pain and pathological fractures. Bone marrow examination shows macrophages with characteristic crumbled tissue paper appearance.

Option D: Galactocerebrosidase deficiency is seen in Krabbe disease. Both peripheral and central myelin is affected in this disease. The patients present with spasticity and intellectual impairment (destruction of central myelin) and peripheral neuropathy and absent deep tendon reflexes (destruction of peripheral myelin). Optic atrophy may also be seen.

questions.text: Which of the following conversions requires pantothenic acid as an essential cofactor?
questions.solution:
Pantothenic acid is an essential cofactor of coenzyme A which is required for the reaction involving the transfer of acyl group such as oxaloacetate to citrate.

In the first step of the TCA cycle, acetyl CoA combines with oxaloacetate to form citrate involving the transfer of acetyl group to oxaloacetate. Also in the same cycle, succinyl CoA synthesis from alpha-ketoglutarate requires coenzyme A.

There are a variety of biochemical reactions that require CoA such as fatty acid synthesis and beta-oxidation.

Deficiency of pantothenic acid (vitamin B5) causes peripheral nerve damage also known as burning foot syndrome.


Other options: 

Option A: Conversion of glucose to pyruvate in aerobic glycolysis requires the coenzyme NAD+ (vitamin B3). This reaction does not require coenzyme A.

Option B: Glutamate dehydrogenase which converts glutamate to alpha-ketoglutarate utilizes NAD+ or NADP+ as a coenzyme.

Option C: Conversion of glucose to ribose-5-phosphate in the hexose monophosphate shunt requires the coenzyme NADP+ (vitamin B3).

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the given graph?

choices.text: Inhibitor binds to the active site
Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site
Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition
Vmax decreases and Kmax is unchanged

questions.solution:
The given graph shows competitive inhibition in which the value of Vmax remains constant and the Km value increases.

When the active site or catalytic site of an enzyme is occupied by a substance other than the substrate of that enzyme, this type of inhibition is known as Competitive inhibition. eg: succinate dehydrogenase reaction is inhibited by malonate. The inhibitor binds to the active site. The inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site. Competitive Inhibition is reversible.

 

Lineweaver Burk Plot for other enzyme inhibition,

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with a defect in collagen maturity?
questions.solution:
Scurvy is associated with a defect in collagen maturity.

Scurvy results from ascorbic acid or vitamin C deficiency. Vitamin C is an essential cofactor for the enzyme prolyl hydroxylase, required for the hydroxylation of prolyl residues in collagen. This enables each collagen fibril to form a uniform and flexible triple helix configuration in the body’s connective tissues.

Its deficiency results in a defective prolyl hydroxylase activity, thereby resulting in the impaired formation of mature connective tissue; the clinical manifestations of this deficiency include petechiae, ecchymosis, coiled hairs, inflamed and bleeding gums, joint effusion, tooth loss, bone fracture,  poor wound healing, and fatigue which can be attributed to impaired collagen synthesis all of which are typical of scurvy.

Risk factors include chronic alcoholism, diseases such as celiac disease and Crohn’s disease, associated with malabsorption and poor nutrition.

It is treated with vitamin C supplementation. 

Other options:

Option B- Rickets is caused due to deficiency of vitamin D in children which is characterized by the continued formation of the collagen matrix of bone but its incomplete mineralization or demineralization. Children have soft, pliable bones. 

Option C- Beriberi is caused due to deficiency of thiamine. It can either be dry beriberi characterized by peripheral neuropathy or wet beriberi characterized by edema due to dilated cardiomyopathy.

Option D- Night blindness is caused by a deficiency of vitamin A. Deficiency can also lead to pancreatic insufficiency, repeated gastrointestinal, pulmonary, and urinary infections, and xeropthalmia.

questions.text: Which of the following has the highest glycemic index?
questions.solution:
The Glycemic index is highest for glucose.

The increase in blood glucose after a test dose of carbohydrate compared with that after an equivalent amount of glucose (as glucose or from a reference starchy food) is known as the glycemic index.

Glycemic Index:

  • Glucose and galactose: 1
  • Dietary fibers: 0

Low glycemic index:

  • Fructose
  • Sucrose
  • Starch
  • Sugar alcohol

questions.text: A neonate presents with feeding difficulty and failure to thrive. Her urine has a peculiar burnt sugar odor due to an excess of branched-chain amino acids. Which of the following is unlikely to be elevated?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of maple syrup urine disease (MSUD). Lysine is not a branched-chain amino acid and hence is unlikely to be elevated.

Branched-chain amino acids are:

  • Valine (V)
  • Isoleucine (I)
  • Leucine (L)

MSUD is due to the deficiency of branched-chain alpha-keto acid dehydrogenase complex (BCKDC), leading to the formation of branched-chain amino acids and their toxic by-products (ketoacids) in the blood and urine. There is a peculiar odor of burnt sugar found in urine, sweat, and cerumen.

Related Pearl: Maple syrup urine disease(MSUD)

questions.text:
Match the following mucopolysaccharidoses with the defective enzyme in each case:
Mucopolysaccharidosis Defective enzyme
1. Hunter syndrome A. α-l-Iduronidase
2. Morquio syndrome B B. Iduronate sulfatase
3. Hurler syndrome C. Heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase
4. Sanfilippo syndrome A D. β-galactosidase
questions.solution:
The option showing 1-B, 2-D 3-A, 4-C  is correctly matched.

Mucopolysaccharidosis Defective enzyme
1. Hunter syndrome B. Iduronate sulfatase
2. Morquio syndrome B D. β-galactosidase
3. Hurler syndrome A. α-l-Iduronidase
4. Sanfilippo syndrome A C. Heparan sulfate-N-sulfatase

 

Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) or mucopolysaccharides are complex carbohydrates made up of amino sugars and uronic acids. When they are attached to a protein they are referred to as proteoglycans. These proteoglycans make up a large part of the extracellular matrix and connective tissue.

Defects in the enzymes that degrade GAGs result in the mucopolysaccharidoses mentioned above. These defects are commonly inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern. Accumulation of GAGs in the tissue can result in organomegaly, cartilage and bone abnormalities, facial abnormalities, problems with mental development, etc.

Related Pearl: Biologically important Glycosoaminoglycans(GAG's)

GAG

Disaccharide repeat units

Keratan sulfate

N Acetyl Glucosamine + Galactose

Hyaluronic acid

N Acetyl Glucosamine + Glucuronic acid

Chondroitin sulfate

N Acetyl Galactosamine + Glucuronic acid

Dermatan Sulfate

N Acetyl Galactosamine + Iduronic/ Glucuronic acid

Heparan sulfate

N Acetyl(Fewer N-sulphated than Heparin)Glucosamine + Glucuronic acid

Heparin

N Sulphated Glucosamine + Iduronic acid
